snippet.textDisplay: Excellent tutorial for this not-very-experienced seamstress! I was able to use some jewelry wire since I didn't have pipe cleaners around. Since I didn't want the wire poking our faces since it's harder than pipe cleaner, I made it the full length of the mask. My husband didn't want tie-ribbons and we didn't have elastic, so I was able to make the strings wrap around the ear, but that does require measuring individual faces/ears. Currently using a Chemex coffee filter for the insert, but looking for something more substantial. Thank you!
snippet.textOriginal: Excellent tutorial for this not-very-experienced seamstress! I was able to use some jewelry wire since I didn't have pipe cleaners around. Since I didn't want the wire poking our faces since it's harder than pipe cleaner, I made it the full length of the mask. My husband didn't want tie-ribbons and we didn't have elastic, so I was able to make the strings wrap around the ear, but that does require measuring individual faces/ears. Currently using a Chemex coffee filter for the insert, but looking for something more substantial. Thank you!

snippet.textDisplay: Thanks for doing your video and giving such good guidance but I felt like this video took too long to watch, the mask took too long to make and used too much bias tape.  You may have all that time to make and press your own bias tape but I have a lot of masks to make for friends and family because how many people have sewing machines!! :-)  I used the Hobby Lobby DIY Mask (Love it) and added an iron in polyester interfacing which adds to the safety of the mask.  As well, instead of zig zagging the pipe cleaner in, I just did a simple stitch next to it and on both ends.  It worked just as well and avoided the risk of breaking needles.
snippet.textOriginal: Thanks for doing your video and giving such good guidance but I felt like this video took too long to watch, the mask took too long to make and used too much bias tape.  You may have all that time to make and press your own bias tape but I have a lot of masks to make for friends and family because how many people have sewing machines!! :-)  I used the Hobby Lobby DIY Mask (Love it) and added an iron in polyester interfacing which adds to the safety of the mask.  As well, instead of zig zagging the pipe cleaner in, I just did a simple stitch next to it and on both ends.  It worked just as well and avoided the risk of breaking needles.

snippet.textDisplay: HI Melanie.  It's easier to just use one piece of fabric 8x15.  I've tricked out many designs of face masks because there are too many steps for beginner sewers.  My team has made hundreds of masks for area nursing homes, hospitals and homeless shelters.  The more steps there are to making a mask, the harder it is to turn them out.
snippet.textOriginal: HI Melanie.  It's easier to just use one piece of fabric 8x15.  I've tricked out many designs of face masks because there are too many steps for beginner sewers.  My team has made hundreds of masks for area nursing homes, hospitals and homeless shelters.  The more steps there are to making a mask, the harder it is to turn them out.

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you for making these. I’ve been looking for rather specific tutorials, and yours fit the bill. For everyone wondering how to make the bias tape without the tool, there is a trick I found with a large needle and an ironing board, but I used a thick towel folded in half for convenience. Works great. Here’s the link: https://creativelittledaisy.typepad.com/creative_little_daisy/2007/11/diy-version-of.html
snippet.textOriginal: Thank you for making these. I’ve been looking for rather specific tutorials, and yours fit the bill. For everyone wondering how to make the bias tape without the tool, there is a trick I found with a large needle and an ironing board, but I used a thick towel folded in half for convenience. Works great. Here’s the link: https://creativelittledaisy.typepad.com/creative_little_daisy/2007/11/diy-version-of.html

https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/making-your-own-face-mask-some-fabrics-work-better-others-n1175966
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
This mask would also work great with the elastic. I prefer the elastic with the filter option.

Also, instead of using wire for the nose .. I made pleats going in opposite directions on each side of the nose with about a 1" or less in between and it cinched the nose area really nicely. I tagged you on my Instagram for my sample.
snippet.textOriginal:
This mask would also work great with the elastic. I prefer the elastic with the filter option. 

Also, instead of using wire for the nose .. I made pleats going in opposite directions on each side of the nose with about a 1" or less in between and it cinched the nose area really nicely. I tagged you on my Instagram for my sample.

snippet.textDisplay: Love the look and the pocket design. However, my brand new machine is pretty basic and it DID NOT like the multi-layers when doing the pleats. snippet.textDisplay: I gave this a try. I’m an intermediate sewer (meaning I’ve taken classes and can sew dresses and pockets). This was easy to follow/understand but unnecessarily difficult and time consuming. Since people are looking to make several of these, i don’t recommend this. There is extra fabric being used. Here’s another tutorial I found to be much easier and used less materials: https://youtu.be/jYMkW469NNc

snippet.textDisplay:
Just a few quick suggestions if you don't have pipe cleaners for a fitted mask (not all ideal, but we can use what we have):

* Twist Ties given in garbage bag boxes (some might have a "paper covering" over the wire while others might have plastic)
* Twist Ties used for bags containing bread; hamburger & hot dog buns; bagels; tortillas; etc al. (again, some might have a "paper covering" over the wire while others might have plastic)
*Garden wire (usually made with a wire inside & covered w/a green plastic -- used to help support plants).

Good luck everyone & a big thank you to all who are making these for their communities! 👍
snippet.textOriginal:
Just a few quick suggestions if you don't have pipe cleaners for a fitted mask (not all ideal, but we can use what we have): 

* Twist Ties given in garbage bag boxes (some might have a "paper covering" over the wire while others might have plastic)
* Twist Ties used for bags containing bread;  hamburger & hot dog buns; bagels; tortillas; etc al. (again, some might have a "paper covering" over the wire while others might have plastic)
*Garden wire (usually made with a wire inside & covered w/a green plastic -- used to help support plants).

Good luck everyone & a big thank you to all who are making these for their communities! 👍

snippet.textDisplay: One hack for making the tape if you don't have the bias tape maker:  Pin a  safety pin to the ironing board.  Finger-press the fabric for the tie and thread it through the safety pin, then pull it through and hit it with the iron as you go.
snippet.textOriginal: One hack for making the tape if you don't have the bias tape maker:  Pin a  safety pin to the ironing board.  Finger-press the fabric for the tie and thread it through the safety pin, then pull it through and hit it with the iron as you go.

snippet.textDisplay: Your pleats should be deeper, so the fabric does not gap at sides, the mask should be fitted as close around your face as possible

snippet.textDisplay: Thanks much this video was a great help and my 1st mask came out close to perfect. I didn't have any pipe cleaner, but I did have some bendable wire I had gotten in the hardware section of the dollar tree. I cut a 4 inch piece then I put it between some masking tape, though I would have preferred using surgical tape since it has material. I  also sewed it with the zigzag to hold it in place and that worked perfectly. I was almost finished at close to 2 am since I started my project late, and on the last 2 inches of  tie #2 ran out of bobbin thread...calling it a night/morning and will finish up when I wake. Thanks again Melanie ! You are awesome !
snippet.textOriginal: Thanks much this video was a great help and my 1st mask came out close to perfect. snippet.textDisplay: This is an amazing tutorial. Thank you so very much! I wanted to share with everyone that if, like me, you can't get your hands on a bias tape maker (they're sold out everywhere), you can make one with cardboard that works just as well! I followed the instructions from this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yIY7ldNY8w8 Just adjust her measurements so that you're making the strips to the size you need! Also, Kona rolls are perfect to use for straps and are already pre-cut and measured. Much cheaper and easy to find right now. :-)
snippet.textOriginal: This is an amazing tutorial. Thank you so very much! I wanted to share with everyone that if, like me, you can't get your hands on a bias tape maker (they're sold out everywhere), you can make one with cardboard that works just as well! I followed the instructions from this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yIY7ldNY8w8     Just adjust her measurements so that you're making the strips to the size you need!  Also, Kona rolls are perfect to use for straps and are already pre-cut and measured. Much cheaper and easy to find right now.   :-)

snippet.textDisplay:
Lots of discussion on the best materials the last few days... but I'd just like to emphasize a couple of points:

1) the combination of your fabric/materials MUST BE BREATHABLE. Many videos appear to use fabric that looks way to thick. Hold the layers up to your mouth, if you can't reasonably breathe through the layers - then the wearer will end up breathing around the mask rather than through the mask, thereby significantly diminishing the mask's effectiveness.

2) Seems like most experts are agreeing that 100% cotton is the best fabric for most home made masks; t-shirts and bed sheets (reasonably tightly woven) are getting many recommendations and are readily available. I have had good luck with three layers of well worn/washed cotton sateen sheets. I'm guessing about 600 thread count. Also, the US Surgeon General has a video on how to make a mask out of a cotton t-shirt.

3) As a bonus, you can also use the elastic from a fitted sheet as ties.

4) be very very very cautious of any materials designed for cleaning or other specialty purposes (e.g., vacuum cleaner bags, disposable diapers, microfiber towels, etc...), they may (probably) have hazardous chemicals resulting from the manufacturing or treatment processes.

5) I found the pipe cleaners not quite strong stiff enough for my needs. Paper clips weren't any better. Try standard 16 gauge solid insulated house wiring (just one wire, not the combination of 3 or 4 wires in standard house wiring). It works very well. Just curl the ends back and crimp. It won't rust and the insulation provides a bit of cushion. Often hardware stores have small scraps laying around and will give them away for free.

...
snippet.textOriginal:
Lots of discussion on the best materials the last few days... but I'd just like to emphasize a couple of points:  

1) the combination of your fabric/materials MUST BE BREATHABLE. Many videos appear to use fabric that looks way to thick.  Hold the layers up to your mouth, if you can't reasonably breathe through the layers - then the wearer will end up breathing around the mask rather than through the mask, thereby significantly diminishing the mask's effectiveness.  

2) Seems like most experts are agreeing that 100% cotton is the best fabric for most home made masks;  t-shirts and bed sheets (reasonably tightly woven) are getting many recommendations and are readily available. I have had good luck with three layers of well worn/washed cotton sateen sheets. I'm guessing about 600 thread count. Also, the US Surgeon General has a video on how to make a mask out of a cotton t-shirt.

3) As a bonus, you can also use the elastic from a fitted sheet as ties.     

4) be very very very cautious of any materials designed for cleaning or other specialty purposes (e.g., vacuum cleaner bags, disposable diapers, microfiber towels, etc...), they may (probably) have hazardous chemicals resulting from the manufacturing or treatment processes.

5) I found the pipe cleaners not quite strong stiff enough for my needs. Paper clips weren't any better.  Try standard 16 gauge solid insulated house wiring (just one wire, not the combination of 3 or 4 wires in standard house wiring).  It works very well.  Just curl the ends back and crimp. It won't rust and the insulation provides a bit of cushion.  Often hardware stores have small scraps laying around and will give them away for free.

snippet.textDisplay:
May I ask a few questions:
What type of fabrics do you use for the mask front, pockets, and for the strips?
Do we use polyester thread with polyester fabric, cotton thread with cotton fabric, etc..?
Is it necessary to wash the fabric before cutting the 6" x 9" piece? (shrinkage)
What kind of filter goes into the pocket?
Regarding the pipe fitter, is it possible to do the zig zag stitch first, then insert the pipe cleaner? (I'm clumsy enough to break a needle)
And a suggestion,
Perhaps use a fork instead of a seam ripper when creating the pleat, to prevent cutting the side of the pocket..?
Thank you!
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
Please Forward to all sewers everywhere. I don’t know how to post this on line. Anybody receiving this, please pass it on as you see fit.

I am sewing masks for one person who has had a brain injury and tying strings behind the head is just too hard. I also am sewing for one person who has the use of only one hand, as well as for a number of people with bad shoulder injuries. I don’t have elastic, so I have been using cloth ribbon.

To make a mask that you can put on one handed or which requires tying no strings, or reaching behind the head ( can be used for either pleated or contoured masks):

1. Determine which side is the persons most mobile side.
2. On that side, sew in two button holes on the edge of the mask, top and bottom.
3. On the other side sew in the ends of the ties.
4. Thread ties through button holes.
5. If you can find them, put both ties through a plastic spring toggle such as are used on stuff sacks.
6. Knot ends of ties so they don’t come back out of the toggle.
7. Even if you don’t have a toggle, this allows mask to be put on and adjusted by tying only one set of strings and it is not behind your head so you can see it in a mirror and you are not stretching your shoulders.

Happy sewing and godspeed to all

Doris
snippet.textOriginal:
Please Forward to all sewers everywhere. I don’t know how to post this on line. Anybody receiving this, please pass it on as you see fit.

I am sewing masks for one person who has had a brain injury and tying strings behind the head is just too hard.  I also am sewing for one person who has the use of only one hand, as well as for a number of people with bad shoulder injuries. I don’t have elastic, so I have been using cloth ribbon.  

To make a mask that you can put on one handed or which requires tying no strings, or reaching behind the head ( can be used for either pleated or contoured masks):

1. Determine which side is the persons most mobile side. 
2. On that side, sew in two button holes on the edge of the mask, top and bottom. 
3. On the other side sew in the ends of the ties.
4. Thread ties through button holes.
5. If you can find them, put both ties through a plastic spring toggle such as are used on stuff sacks.
6. Knot ends of ties so they don’t come back out of the toggle. 
7. Even if you don’t have a toggle, this allows mask to be put on and adjusted by tying only one set of strings and it is not behind your head so you can see it in a mirror and you are not stretching your shoulders. 

Happy sewing and godspeed to all

Doris

snippet.textDisplay: Hey Ms. Ham--what do you use for filters please? Thank you in advance.
snippet.textOriginal: Hey Ms. Ham--what do you use for filters please? Thank you in advance.

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you so much for the Tie video. I found your 10 Minute video last night, but don’t have any elastic on hand. I actually gave away lots of sewing supplies a few months ago. But I have lots of fabric. Today...sewing masks!
snippet.textOriginal: Thank you so much for the Tie video. I found your 10 Minute video last night, but don’t have any elastic on hand. I actually gave away lots of sewing supplies a few months ago. But I have lots of fabric. Today...sewing masks!

snippet.textDisplay: Negative: As everyone is feeling, I hate that I am looking up videos for this kind of thing to make a few for my elderly father. Positive: The seam ripper pleats and pipe cleaners for the nose, oh my gosh...amazing! Melanie, thank you for making this video in such a clear and clean method.
snippet.textOriginal: Negative: As everyone is feeling, I hate that I am looking up videos for this kind of thing to make a few for my elderly father. Positive: The seam ripper pleats and pipe cleaners for the nose, oh my gosh...amazing! Melanie, thank you for making this video in such a clear and clean method.

snippet.textDisplay: Do the pipe cleaners rust in the wash?

snippet.textDisplay: Oh sure, they made fun of the girls in Home Economics class in high school, but who's laughing now? Yeah. Nerd girls will live. All the divas will die! The ability to sew. I'll be in the die category. Revenge of the nerds.

snippet.textDisplay: Wow I’ve never seen the pleats made with the use of seam ripper like you showed us ! Thank you.

snippet.textDisplay: Waaay overcomplicated.  By the time you finish one mask the pandemic will be over.  Pipe cleaners will rust too.  Bad.
